bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, February 16, 1929

div1.p: Carter updates Russell on the progress being made on the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, February 16, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel, Report (weekly)
Russell G.F.F.
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
February 16, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I intended writing you yesterday as to the progress on the book
during the past week, but after having recast and re-typed bibliographic cards from 830 A.M. until
3 P. M. I decided I had best take back a lot of books to the Library of
Congress, since their time would soon expire. Also, I wanted to check
some further references at the Library. While there, Miss Brown sug-
gested that I should dine with her and then go to her apartment and
check the work she has been doing since our last night session. We
put in four hours of steady work and I got home, somewhat “the worse for
wear,” about 11 P. M. However, it was a very satisfactory day.

In the retyping of the remaining bibliographic cards for Dr. Frost,
I am really surprised myself at how much ground we have covered, even
without counting the medical references, which Dr. Frost has already
incorporated in Section i and Section ii.

I expect to go over to Baltimore about next Thursday and hope to
get good news re the final editing when I get there. Have heard nothing
from Dr. Frost personally for some time.

Thank you very much for transmitting my request for information as to the amount of my total com-
pensation last year, to Mr. Gillette. I have heard from him and am also
writing to thank him personally.
div1.closer:
With best remembrances, I remain
Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
